content: The "Minority Inclusion in Clinical Trials Act of 2015" emphasizes the need to increase representation of underrepresented communities in clinical trials, as stated by the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants for expanding opportunities for scientists and researchers and promoting the inclusion of underrepresented minorities in the health professions. SEC. 4. SUPPORT FOR INSTITUTIONS COMMITTED TO WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT IN UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITIES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible entities committed to health workforce development in underrepresented communities, including educational institutions producing underrepresented minority health professionals. To be eligible for a grant under subsection (a), an entity must be an educational institution historically producing underrepresented minority health professionals, including historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving health professions schools, tribal colleges, and institutions serving Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander populations. Entities eligible for grants under subsection (a) include historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving health professions schools, tribal colleges and universities, Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions, institutions with programs to recruit and retain underrepresented minority health professionals, health professional associations, and institutions located in communities with underrepresented minorities. Entities eligible for grants under subsection (a) include health professional associations, institutions located in communities with predominantly underrepresented minority populations, and institutions with partnerships for increasing workforce diversity. These institutions must have at least 20 percent of enrolled participants who are underrepresented minorities. The grant recipients must have at least 20 percent of enrolled participants who are underrepresented minorities. The funds received are to be used for expanding, implementing, or evaluating workforce diversity programs, including mental health. The grant funds must be used to expand, implement, or evaluate workforce diversity programs, including mental health care professions. Activities may include educational outreach, scholarships, postbaccalaureate programs, and considering minority status in qualifications. The curr_chunk focuses on various programs related to opportunities in the health professions, including educational outreach, scholarships, postbaccalaureate programs, academic enrichment, mentoring, internship programs, and community partnerships. The curr_chunk discusses pipeline programs, mentoring programs, internship programs in healthcare settings, community partnership development for diversity, and leadership training. Grantees must submit reports evaluating activities conducted under the grant. The term "Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions" is defined in this section. The curr_chunk discusses the requirement for grantees to submit a report summarizing and evaluating activities conducted under the grant. It also defines the term "Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions" and authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 2015 through 2020. Eliminating disparities in maternity health outcomes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with various health organizations, is tasked with addressing disparities in maternity health outcomes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with national stakeholder organizations, will conduct research and expand access to services to eliminate disparities in maternal health outcomes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services aims to reduce disparities in maternal care and health outcomes by expanding access to proven services and implementing interventions to improve maternity care for vulnerable populations. A demonstration project will be established to compare the effectiveness of these interventions in selected states. The Secretary of Health and Human Services plans to reduce disparities in maternity services and outcomes by implementing interventions in up to 8 selected states. States will be chosen based on applications specifying regions and populations to be served, following criteria set by the Secretary. The Secretary will select up to 8 states for a demonstration project to reduce disparities in maternity services. Criteria will ensure representation of affected communities, test various models, and include evidence-based interventions. The demonstration project aims to reduce disparities in maternity services by testing various models with evidence-based interventions. The project will involve consultation with local and regional provider organizations and will run from January 1, 2015, to December 31, 2019. The demonstration project, starting on January 1, 2015, and ending on December 31, 2019, includes grants for evaluation and monitoring by the Secretary. States participating in the project must submit reports. The State participating in the demonstration project must submit reports to the Secretary containing data for monitoring project outcomes, costs, and quality of maternity care. The Secretary will evaluate the costs and quality of maternity care provided in the project, as well as the rationale for bundled payments. A final report on the project results must be submitted to Congress by December 31, 2020. SEC. 6. HEALTH DISPARITIES EDUCATION PROGRAM. The Secretary will establish a health and health care disparities education program in collaboration with various entities to inform professionals and the public about reducing racial and ethnic disparities in health care. The Secretary will establish an education program to inform healthcare professionals and the public about reducing racial and ethnic disparities in health and healthcare through outreach campaigns and dissemination of scientific evidence. The medical community aims to disseminate scientific evidence on racial and ethnic disparities in healthcare, including factors beyond access to care or patient preferences. This includes disparities related to age, disability status, socioeconomic status, sex, gender identity, and sexual orientation among minorities. The initiative aims to address disparities in healthcare for racial and ethnic minorities, as well as other factors like age, disability, socioeconomic status, sex, gender identity, and sexual orientation. It also focuses on disseminating research findings to healthcare providers and patients to reduce and eliminate disparities, including linguistic and cultural barriers. The initiative aims to reduce healthcare disparities for various demographics and disseminate information on language access services, data collection, and educational initiatives. The initiative aims to address disparities in healthcare for different demographics by collecting data on racial, ethnic, disability, socioeconomic status, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation, and primary language. It also includes implementing educational programs for healthcare providers and assessing the impact of these initiatives. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of these programs. The section focuses on raising awareness of health disparities and available resources. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2015 through 2020.
